critique: This executive order establishes an administration to handle surplus war property during World War II. It centralizes control over the disposition of these assets under the Office of War Mobilization. There's a moderate expansion of executive power due to the broad authority granted to the Administrator. Economically, it leans towards government intervention as it manages and directs the flow of surplus property. It is difficult to assess its impact on social inclusion, immigration, or civil liberties based on the text. The order strengthens federal control over resources, indicating a move towards federal primacy. There is no clear ideological tilt.
